item.title: Jon Stewart Defends Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: “The Daily Show” host said it shouldn’t be a performer’s job to unify the country: “Isn’t there another person whose job description is much more along those lines?”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Have I Got News for You (TV Program)

item.title: Haruki Murakami no le teme a la oscuridad
item.description: El autor, quien dio proyección mundial a la literatura japonesa, reflexiona sobre el envejecimiento y su lugar en el mundo de las letras.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter

media:content.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times

item.title: Word of the Day: indigent
item.description: This word has appeared in 36 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Bangladesh Exposed the Deeper Problem Facing Democracy
item.description: Toppling autocrats is easier than rebuilding the institutions democracy depends on.
item.dc:creator: Zahid Hussain and Tom Felix Joehnk

item.title: The Epstein Files Are Coming for Keir Starmer
item.description: Even longtime admirers see the writing on the wall for Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Moya Lothian-McLean

item.title: Nicaragua Blocks a Route from Cuba to the U.S.
item.description: The Trump administration has criticized Nicaragua for serving as an illegal immigration pathway to the United States.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

media:content.media:description: Cubans lining up outside the Nicaraguan Embassy in Havana on Monday, after Nicaragua ended visa-free entry for Cuban citizens.

item.title: A Shift in Chinese Taste for Durian Throws Malaysian Farmers Into Turmoil
item.description: Malaysian durian farmers saw immense profits over the last decade as China snapped up their produce. But tastes have shifted.
item.dc:creator: Zunaira Saieed and Lauren DeCicca

media:content.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: How Italy’s Police and Army Compete to Enlist Italian Olympians
item.description: Most Italian athletes at the Winter Games subsidize their training by joining the police or the military, which vie to enlist the best talent.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Italian curler Amos Mosaner.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 10, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 10, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: The Cradle of Pasta Is Heaven for Olympians
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 10, 2025.

item.title: Appeals Court Lets Trump Revoke Deportation Protections for 60,000 More Migrants
item.description: The court pointed to recent rulings by the Supreme Court as precedent to allow the protections for migrants from Nepal, Honduras and Nicaragua to expire.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Sebastian Hidalgo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A family from Honduras at a park in northern Illinois in 2023. The Temporary Protected Status program allows people from countries facing war or other instability to temporarily live and work in the United States.

item.title: A Campaign to Revoke the Endangerment Finding Appears Near ‘Total Victory’
item.description: A small group of conservative activists has worked for 16 years to stop all government efforts to fight climate change. Their efforts seem poised to pay off.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:description: Russell Vought, speaking at the White House in 2019, was part of the core group that prepared the repeal strategy.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 10, 2026
item.description: Sarah Sinclair and Amie Walker’s collaboration will cheer you up.
item.dc:creator: Myq Kaplan

media:content.media:description: Neal Schon, left, and Arnel Pineda from the band Journey in 2022.

item.title: U.S. Boat Strike Kills 2 in Pacific, With One Survivor
item.description: The strike in the eastern Pacific, the third on suspected drug trafficking boats this year, was the second authorized by Gen. Francis L. Donovan, the new head of the Southern Command.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:description: Gen. Francis L. Donovan, a Marine, took charge of U.S. military operations in Latin America and the Caribbean last week.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Block Opening of Gordie Howe International Bridge to Canada
item.description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge, expected to open early this year, was built by Canada to ease cargo transport between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge connecting Detroit to Windsor, Ontario is expected to open early this year.

item.title: How a Decision to Use Whistles as a Prop Cost Eric Adams $4,000
item.description: The former New York mayor paid a Conflicts of Interest Board fine for having City Hall employees assist in attacking former Gov. Andrew Cuomo over sexual harassment allegations.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)

media:content.media:credit: Olga Fedorova for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams used whistles as a prop during a news conference at City Hall last August while he was campaigning for re-election.

item.title: U.S. Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen to Be Beatified, One Step Away From Sainthood
item.description: The move involving Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, who hosted a popular midcentury radio and TV show and died in 1979, ends a six-year delay.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham

media:content.media:description: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen delivering a sermon in 1979. He was most famous for his television program, “Life Is Worth Living,” which ran in the 1950s.

item.title: La lección de historia de Bad Bunny en el Super Bowl
item.description: La superestrella exhibió el orgullo puertorriqueño en un espectáculo de 13 minutos que convirtió un escenario global en una actuación íntima y personal.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica

item.title: Georgia Judge Dismisses Case Over 2020 Election Ballots Seized by Justice Dept.
item.description: A state judge dismissed a case after the Justice Department’s seizure of ballots from the 2020 presidential election in Fulton County, which has raised fears that they could be manipulated.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents searched the Fulton County Election Hub and Operation Center in Georgia last month.

item.title: N.Y.C. Social Services Chief Resigns After Losing Mamdani’s Favor
item.description: Molly Wasow Park, a holdover from the Eric Adams administration, said her resignation was unrelated to the recent wave of cold-related deaths in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Mihir Zaveri

media:content.media:description: Molly Wasow Park, the commissioner of the New York City Department of Social Services, said it was becoming clear that Mayor Zohran Mamdani did not intend to retain her.

item.title: Trump Administration Abandons Steve Bannon Conviction
item.description: The longtime Trump ally served four months in prison on contempt of Congress charges for refusing to testify to the House committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media:content.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The government’s attempt to dismiss the indictment against Stephen K. Bannon would have limited practical effect, but would effectively wipe out his conviction.

item.title: A Gray Wolf’s Visit to Los Angeles County Is a First in Nearly a Century
item.description: The wolf, known as BEY03F, roamed more than 500 miles from Northern California, signaling that the species continues to rebound after being wiped out in the state in the 1920s.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka

media:content.media:credit: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
media:content.media:description: The gray wolf known as BEY03F in April 2025.

item.title: Gabbard’s 2020 Election Claims Put Her Back in Favor With Trump
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard has focused on attacking the so-called deep state after an uneven first year as the director of national intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Tyler Pager and Glenn Thrush
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

media:content.media:description: Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, has fallen in and out of favor with President Trump over the last year.

item.title: Israeli President’s Visit to Australia Sets Off Protests
item.description: A visit by the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog, to Australia on Monday to commemorate the victims of the Bondi Beach attack set off protests in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

media:content.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters at a demonstration in Sydney against the visit of President Isaac Herzog of Israel to Australia on Monday.

item.title: How Laura Loomer and a Sheriff Upended G.O.P. Plans for the N.Y. Ticket
item.description: Bruce Blakeman, the likely Republican candidate for governor of New York, had decided on his running mate, but things quickly got complicated.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:description: Bruce Blakeman, the Nassau County executive running for governor of New York, had offered the lieutenant governor slot on the Republican ticket to several people who turned it down.

item.title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Super Bowl, Olympics, Missing Person
item.description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

item.title: Here’s What a Warm Night Looks Like for Homeless New Yorkers
item.description: As weekend temperatures fell into the single digits, New York City operated 65 warming centers where people could find cots, chairs and a respite from the cold.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

media:content.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: At Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan, the south lobby is being used this winter to house homeless New Yorkers at night.

item.title: La boda en el espectáculo de Bad Bunny en el Super Bowl era real
item.description: La pareja que se casó en el estadio había invitado al cantante puertorriqueño a su boda, pero en su lugar recibió una invitación para aparecer en el escenario con él, dijo su representante.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan and Yan Zhuang

media:content.media:description: Los novios, que no fueron identificados por el equipo de Bad Bunny, pueden contar con la estrella del pop como testigo de su boda.

item.title: In the New Jersey Primary, ‘Abolish ICE’ Looks Like a Winning Message
item.description: Trump has thrust us into a new political world, and Democratic voters want leaders who can adapt.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times

item.title: Newly Unbound, Trump Weighs More Nuclear Arms and Underground Tests
item.description: It remains to be seen whether the three big nuclear powers are headed into a new arms race, or whether President Trump is trying to spur negotiations on a new accord now that a last Cold War treaty has expired.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: An underground atomic test at the Nevada Test Site near Yucca Flats in 1955. The last U.S. explosive test of a nuclear weapon was in 1992.

item.title: The Horological Society of New York Achieves Its 160th Year
item.description: Industry figures say the friendly welcome at the Horological Society of New York has a lot to do with its longevity.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Felder and Ashok Sinha

media:content.media:description: Last month, Jenny Montgomery and five other students took a hands-on class on watchmaking at the Horological Society of New York. The group, which was founded in 1866, has recently seen a surge of interest in watches.

item.title: Watch Brands Increasingly Turn to Sports for Spark
item.description: In a cooling market, makers have been putting more emphasis on sponsorships and famous athletic ambassadors, especially in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Robin Swithinbank

item.title: Judge Strikes Down California’s Ban on Masks for Federal Agents
item.description: But the state can require federal agents to display identification, the judge said. The Trump administration had asked the court to block both laws.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:description: A Customs and Border Protection agent in Oakland, Calif., in October. A judge ruled on Monday that California’s mask ban for federal officers was unconstitutional.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie Pleads for Help With Finding Her Mother
item.description: The “Today” show anchor Savannah Guthrie posted a new video on Instagram where she asked for the public’s help in finding her mother who went missing more than a week ago.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Halftime Show
item.description: We weren’t prepared for the emotional roller coaster Bad Bunny Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, took us on.

item.title: Trump Administration to Cut $600 Million in Health Funding From Four States
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, used the grants to support a wide variety of functions, including H.I.V. prevention and surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: Cuts totaling about $600 million will affect funds to health departments and smaller partner organizations, including the Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago.

item.title: Highlights From the 2026 Winter Olympics, in Photos
item.description: As the athletes soared through the air and spun above the ice, New York Times photographers were there to capture the action in Italy.

item.title: The Latest Victim of a Snowless West: Dog Sledding
item.description: Organizers of the Idaho Sled Dog Challenge said they would no longer hold a major competition after snow conditions forced its cancellation for a third straight year.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root

item.title: Starmer Pressured to Resign Over Ambassador’s Ties to Epstein
item.description: The British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has been left on politically unstable ground as more political figures call for his resignation over his appointment of the former ambassador to the United States, Peter Mandelson, who has close ties to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain speaking in southern England on Thursday. Aides told a daily briefing with journalists that Mr. Starmer did not intend to resign.

item.title: Movies to Watch if You Love (or Hate) Valentine’s Day
item.description: Whether you’re thrilled about the holiday or ready to kiss it goodbye, we have great picks for you.

item.title: Meta and YouTube Created ‘Digital Casinos,’ Lawyers Argue in Landmark Trial

item.title: New Email Shows Bard President Leon Botstein Thanked Epstein for Caribbean Trip
item.description: Leon Botstein, Bard’s president, also invited Jeffrey Epstein to visit a high school linked to Bard College and sent him well wishes after stories were published about his sexual abuse of minors.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

media:content.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Leon Botstein has led Bard College since 1975.

item.title: Air Canada Cancels Flights to Cuba as Cuba Runs Out of Jet Fuel
item.description: The Trump administration’s crackdown on oil shipments to Cuba is beginning to wreak havoc on the Caribbean island’s travel industry.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Air Canada planes at Vancouver International Airport. The airline announced on Monday that it had suspended its 16 flights per week to four Cuban cities. Canada is the top source of tourists to Cuba.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara Died From Pulmonary Embolism, Death Certificate Says
item.description: A death certificate released on Monday also said rectal cancer was an underlying cause for the comedic actress’s death on Jan. 30 at 71.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Matt Stevens

media:content.media:description: The actress Catherine O’Hara in 2024. She died on Jan. 30 at 71.

item.title: Venezuela vuelve a detener a Juan Pablo Guanipa tras liberarlo
item.description: Juan Pablo Guanipa, uno de los dirigentes de la oposición más conocidos, fue liberado y luego detenido de nuevo, lo que ha suscitado dudas sobre la dirección del gobierno interino del país.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times

item.title: Starmer’s Epstein Crisis
item.description: Among the powerful men facing fallout from the files, the one in deepest trouble appears to have never met Epstein: the British prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is facing calls to resign over the Epstein scandal.

item.title: Olympic Athletes Jump For Joy and Break Their Medals
item.description: As Olympians report their medals detaching from their ribbons, game organizers are scrambling to fix the issue. This is not the first time that Olympic medals have had issues. Over a 100 athletes from the Paris Olympics in 2024 reported that their medals deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Breezy Johnson of the United States posing with her gold medal for downhill skiing at the medal ceremony on Sunday.
